newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dlr ends with weak tone as bonds, shares fall.
newsitem.headline: NZ dlr ends with weak tone as bonds, shares fall.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar closed a touch weaker on Thursday as sell-offs in the bond and share markets flowed through into the currency.
The Kiwi finished at US$0.6930/37 and 68.22 on its Trade-Weighted Index, from 0.6936/41 and 68.47 at the opening.
"The bond market, the equities market, they've all come in for a bit of selling pressure and clearly some of that's flowing through into the currency as well," said Phillip Lindberg at Bankers Trust.

Bond market weakness was exacerbated by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan voicing concern about the risk of higher inflation, while the equities market was reacting mainly to disappointing earnings reports.

Dealers said some early exporter buying of the Kiwi was checked by U.S. selling as the currency moved in a narrow 0.6932-45 range on the day, with little reaction to government fiscal figures and January merchandise trade data.

Bankers Trust economists said the NZ$134 monthly trade deficit was well below expectations and consistent with the view of a reasonable external sector performance and stable current account deficit this year. They called the data mildly positive for the currency and bonds.
A Wellington dealers said there were bids for the New Zealand dollar around 0.6925-30 and he saw it in a 0.6930-60 range. -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
